study.title: Patterns of infections, aetiological agents and antimicrobial resistance at a tertiary care hospital in northern Tanzania

design.inclusion_criteria_text: Inpatients admitted to medical or surgical wards at KCMC, Moshi, Tanzania, from August 2013 to August 2015, with suspected infection (wound, pneumonia, tuberculosis, septicemia, diarrhoea, meningitis).
design.exclusion_criteria_text: Specimens with insufficient quantity; patients with incomplete information.

eligibility.population: Inpatients (adults and children) admitted to medical or surgical wards with suspected infection (wound, pneumonia, tuberculosis, septicemia, diarrhoea, meningitis).
eligibility.intervention: Not specified; empirical antibiotic treatment prior to admission was common.

populations.description: All inpatients admitted to medical and surgical wards with suspected infection; 575 patients, 590 specimens (286 wound swabs, 126 blood, 122 sputum, 56 stool).

provenance.text_snippet: Table 1 summarises characteristics of 575 patients with different medical conditions enrolled in the study from August 2013 to August 2015.

definitions.resistance_definition_text: Interpretation as susceptible, intermediate resistant and resistant was performed according to CLSI 2013. Isolates with intermediate or resistant results were merged into a single group as resistant during data analysis.
definitions.outcome_definitions_text: No explicit definitions for mortality, LOS, readmission, or cost components.

lab_methods.specimen_collection_method: Stool, sputum, blood, and wound/pus swabs collected from inpatients; blood samples collected in BD BACTEC bottles; wound/pus swabs from wounds due to burns, surgical procedures, diabetes, animal bites, motor traffic accidents, and other injuries.
lab_methods.culture_method: Wound/pus swabs and sputum cultured onto trypticase soy agar with 5% sheep blood, chocolate agar, and McConkey agar; stool on McConkey agar; blood in BD BACTEC incubated up to 5 days.
lab_methods.organism_identification_method: Gram stain, API 20E and/or API NE 20 for Gram-negatives; catalase and coagulase tests for Gram-positives; optochin susceptibility and enzyme latex test for streptococci.
lab_methods.lab_capacity_notes: Samples processed at Kilimanjaro Clinical Research Institute (KCRI) microbiology unit.

amr_proportions.notes: Intermediate and resistant merged as resistant.
Intermediate and resistant merged as resistant.
Intermediate and resistant merged as resistant.
Intermediate and resistant merged as resistant.
All S. aureus tested were resistant to penicillin (100%) and susceptible to vancomycin.
Cefoxitin resistance used to infer MRSA.

risk_factors_effects.notes: Non-significant association between diabetes and Proteus spp infection.
Significant association between wound infection and Proteus spp infection.

policy_capacity.status_text: Samples processed at KCRI microbiology unit; diagnostic capacity present at tertiary hospital.

provenance.text_snippet: All samples were transported immediately after collection to the Kilimanjaro Clinical Research Institute (KCRI), to be processed by the microbiology unit of the biotechnology laboratory department.

codes.subtheme: resistance patterns and rates by pathogen/antibiotic
codes.summary: High rates of resistance to commonly used antibiotics were observed among Gram-negative and Gram-positive isolates, including 100% penicillin resistance in S. aureus and >70% resistance to ampicillin and cefazolin in Proteus and Klebsiella spp.

evidence_quotes.quote: All Staphylococcus aureus tested were resistant to penicillin (n = 22, 100%) and susceptible to vancomycin. Significant resistance to cephalosporins such as cefazolin (n = 62, 72.9%), ceftriaxone (n = 44, 51.8%) and ceftazidime (n = 40, 37.4%) was observed in Gram-negative bacteria, as well as resistance to cefoxitin (n = 6, 27.3%) in S. aureus.

provenance.text_snippet: All Staphylococcus aureus tested were resistant to penicillin (n = 22, 100%) and susceptible to vancomycin.

codes.summary: A majority of patients (71.9%) had received antibiotics prior to admission, with common use of ceftriaxone, metronidazole, and cloxacillin, suggesting widespread empirical and possibly inappropriate antibiotic use.

evidence_quotes.quote: About three-quarters of the patients (n = 412, 71.9%) had a history of antibiotic/antimicrobial treatment before arriving to the hospital (Table 1). Drugs that were commonly used were ceftriaxone (n = 173, 46.2%), metronidazole (n = 147, 39.4%), cloxacillin (n = 64, 17.1%), ciprofloxacin (n = 25, 6.6%) and co-trimoxazole (n = 21, 5.5%).
evidence_quotes.section: Pattern of resistance to antimicrobial agents

provenance.section_heading: Pattern of resistance to antimicrobial agents
provenance.text_snippet: About three-quarters of the patients (n = 412, 71.9%) had a history of antibiotic/antimicrobial treatment before arriving to the hospital (Table 1).

codes.summary: The study highlights the need for regular generation and reporting of data on aetiological agents and antimicrobial susceptibility, with recommendations for sentinel sites and a central organising body.

evidence_quotes.quote: Sentinel sites (hospitals) across the country (and region) should report on a representative subset of bacterial species and their susceptibility to drugs at least annually. A central organising body should collate the data and report to relevant national and international stakeholders.

provenance.text_snippet: Sentinel sites (hospitals) across the country (and region) should report on a representative subset of bacterial species and their susceptibility to drugs at least annually.

notes_flags.detail: No SSI incidence data reported; no explicit surgical site infection definitions.
No ascertainment window for SSI reported.
No data on mortality, reoperations, readmissions, length of stay, or costs.

provenance_index.text_snippet: All Staphylococcus aureus tested were resistant to penicillin (n = 22, 100%) and susceptible to vancomycin.
Table 1 summarises characteristics of 575 patients with different medical conditions enrolled in the study from August 2013 to August 2015.
All samples were transported immediately after collection to the Kilimanjaro Clinical Research Institute (KCRI), to be processed by the microbiology unit of the biotechnology laboratory department.
